1. story_summary = SUMMARIZE(CTX) : Provide a general summary of the story in the input article
2. story_ending = FIND_ENDING(CTX, "story") : Find the ending or conclusion of the story in the input article
3. story_future = FIND_FUTURE(CTX, "story") : Find any hints or predictions about the future of the story in the input article
4. ans = CONCAT(story_summary, story_ending, story_future) : Combine the story summary, ending, and future predictions to form the final answer for comparing with the options
open-answer:
Doctor Universe by Carl Jacobi is a science fiction story set in the future, where the protagonist, Billy, encounters Grannie Annie, a famous science fiction writer who goes by the pen name Annabella C. Flowers. Grannie Annie believes that her latest novel, which revolves around the dangerous Green Flames, a radioactive rock with mind-controlling properties, has been stolen and is being used as a blueprint for a sinister plot. Together, they embark on a journey to Venus to find the lost spaceship containing the Green Flames and stop the villain behind the scheme. Along the way, they face various challenges and obstacles, including a mysterious enemy who seems to be watching their every move.

We reached the door and pulled it open. There was no sign of life.

"Somebody's gone to a lot of trouble here," Ezra Karn observed.

Somebody had. Before us stretched a narrow corridor, flanked on the left side by a wall of impenetrable stepto glass. The corridor was bare of furnishings. But beyond the glass, revealed to us in mocking clarity, was a high panel, studded with dials and gauges. Even as we looked, we could see liquid pulse in glass tubes, indicator needles swing slowly to and fro.

Grannie nodded. "Some kind of a broadcasting unit. The Green Flames in the lower hold are probably exposed to a tholpane plate and their radiations stepped up by an electro-phosicalic process."

Karn raised the butt of his pistol and brought it crashing against the glass wall. His arm jumped in recoil, but the glass remained intact.

"You'll never do it that way," Grannie said. "Nothing short of an atomic blast will shatter that wall. It explains why there are no guards here. The mechanism is entirely self-operating. Let's see if the Green Flames are more accessible."

In the lower hold disappointment again confronted us. Visible in the feeble shafts of daylight that filtered through cracks in the vessel's hull were tiers of rectangular ingots of green iridescent ore. Suspended by insulators from the ceiling over them was a thick metal plate.

But between was a barrier. A wall of impenetrable stepto glass.

Grannie stamped her foot. "It's maddening," she said. "Here we are at the crux of the whole matter, and we're powerless to make a single move."

In the story, Grannie Annie and her companions have discovered the source of the Green Flames, which are causing chaos and unrest throughout the System. They have found a broadcasting unit that is amplifying the radiations of the Green Flames, making them more potent and far-reaching. However, they are unable to destroy the Green Flames or the broadcasting unit due to the impenetrable stepto glass barriers protecting them. The future of the story will likely involve Grannie Annie and her companions trying to find a way to break through the barriers and destroy the Green Flames, in order to restore peace and stability to the System.

open-answer:
The first protagonist, Click Hathaway, is a photographer who works for Cosmic Films and is accompanying Irish Marnagan, an Interplanetary Patrolman, on a mission to capture the space pirate Gunther. Click is initially portrayed as a somewhat nervous and anxious character, constantly worrying about capturing the perfect shot with his camera and not fully grasping the gravity of their situation. He is also shown to be resourceful and quick-thinking, as he figures out that the asteroid monsters they encounter are not real but rather telepathic projections created by Gunther.

Throughout the story, Click undergoes a transformation as he becomes more confident and assertive in his actions. He takes charge of the situation when he and Marnagan are trapped by the monsters, devising a plan to escape and confront Gunther. Click's resourcefulness and determination are further highlighted when he comes up with a clever ruse to trick Gunther and his men into believing that the Interplanetary Patrol has arrived to capture them.

By the end of the story, Click has evolved from a somewhat timid and uncertain character to a more self-assured and decisive individual, capable of taking control of a dangerous situation and using his wits to outsmart a formidable enemy.

The second protagonist in the story is Click Hathaway, a photographer who accompanies Irish Marnagan on their mission to capture the space pirate Gunther. Click is initially portrayed as a nervous and somewhat fearful character, often doubting their chances of survival and success. He is also highly dedicated to his job as a photographer, constantly thinking about capturing the perfect shot for Cosmic Films, even in the face of danger.

Throughout the story, Click undergoes a transformation as he becomes more resourceful and courageous. He uses his knowledge of photography and film to deduce that the asteroid monsters are not real but rather telepathic projections created by Gunther. This realization allows him and Marnagan to overcome their fear of the monsters and continue their mission.

Click's resourcefulness is further demonstrated when he devises a plan to stage a fake raid on Gunther's base, using the telepathic projections to their advantage. He instructs Marnagan on how to act out the scenes, showing his ability to think quickly and adapt to the situation at hand.

In the end, Click's transformation from a nervous photographer to a brave and resourceful partner plays a crucial role in the success of their mission. His newfound courage and determination, along with his unique skills and knowledge, contribute to the capture of Gunther and the completion of their mission.

The relationship between Click Hathaway and Irish Marnagan is initially characterized by a sense of camaraderie and mutual dependence, as they embark on their mission to capture the space pirate Gunther. Despite their differences in personality and approach, they rely on each other for support and encouragement in the face of danger. Click, being the more anxious and uncertain of the two, often looks to Marnagan for reassurance and guidance, while Marnagan appreciates Click's resourcefulness and dedication to his job as a photographer.

As the story progresses, their relationship evolves and deepens, with Click becoming more assertive and confident in his actions. This transformation is largely due to Marnagan's influence and encouragement, as he pushes Click to believe in himself and take charge of the situation. In turn, Click's newfound courage and resourcefulness prove invaluable to their mission, as he devises a plan to outsmart Gunther and his men using the telepathic projections.

Throughout their ordeal, the protagonists maintain a sense of humor and banter, which serves to lighten the mood and strengthen their bond. They also demonstrate a deep sense of loyalty and trust in each other, as they face life-threatening challenges and work together to overcome them.

In conclusion, the relationship between Click Hathaway and Irish Marnagan is one of mutual respect, trust, and growth. Their dynamic partnership allows them to complement each other's strengths and weaknesses, ultimately leading to the successful completion of their mission.

He believes that the return of the Earth-ship would bring disaster to Venus, as it would lead to an influx of immigrants from Earth who would drive the native Venusians into the mud. Svan and his group decide to plant an atomite bomb on the Earth-ship, which would explode after the ship has left Venus. Svan is the one chosen to plant the bomb, but his plan ultimately backfires when another bomb in their car explodes, killing his fellow conspirators and leaving him severely injured.

Svan ends up being the one to plant the bomb, but their plan ultimately fails when another bomb in their car explodes prematurely, killing the conspirators and severely injuring Svan.

The failure of Svan's plan can be attributed to several factors:

1. Mistrust and uncertainty among the conspirators: Svan doubts the loyalty and commitment of his fellow conspirators, believing them to be weak and afraid. This lack of trust leads him to secretly plant a second bomb in their car, which ultimately causes their demise.

5. Svan's overconfidence and poor decision-making: Svan's arrogance and belief in his own abilities lead him to make poor decisions, such as secretly marking his own slip to ensure he is the one to plant the bomb and planting the second bomb in the car. These decisions ultimately contribute to the failure of the plan.

In the story, a series of catastrophic events occur in America, leading to the formation of the Nebraska Sea. It begins with the activation of the Kiowa Fault, causing landslips and earthquakes in Colorado, Wyoming, and New Mexico. As the landslip grows, it affects Kansas, Nebraska, the Dakotas, and Oklahoma, causing the land to sink and forcing millions of people to evacuate. 

On October 21, the second phase of the disaster begins with a massive tidal wave originating from the Gulf of Mexico, swallowing the Mississippi and Alabama coasts and causing widespread destruction. The wave continues to advance, inundating Arkansas, Oklahoma, and parts of Texas. As the land continues to sink, the floodwaters reach Colorado, Missouri, and North Dakota, causing further devastation and loss of life.

By the end of the disaster, over 14 million people have lost their lives, and eight states have been submerged, with only small remnants remaining. The Nebraska Sea is formed, stretching from the Gulf of Mexico to the Dakotas, creating a new inland sea that brings economic and environmental benefits to the surrounding states. The story concludes by highlighting the growth of population, trade, and industry in the states surrounding the new sea, as well as the transformation of cities like Denver, Lincoln, Fargo, Kansas City, and Dallas into world ports and manufacturing centers.

The transformation of America after the events in the input article can be summarized as follows:

2. The climate of the surrounding states became more temperate due to the presence of the sea, making areas like Minnesota and Missouri more habitable.
3. The fishing industry flourished along the coastlines of the Nebraska Sea, contributing significantly to the nation's economy.
4. The sea became a major shipping route, connecting the heart of the continent to the rest of the world and turning cities like Denver, Lincoln, Fargo, Kansas City, and Dallas into world ports and manufacturing centers.
5. The population of the states surrounding the sea experienced a significant increase as water tables rose, and manufacturing and trade moved in to take advantage of the new axis of world communication.
6. The development of new ports and vacation paradises along the coastlines of the Nebraska Sea attracted sailors and tourists from around the world, further boosting the economy and cultural diversity of the region.
7. The political landscape changed as the submerged states struggled to maintain their autonomy, resulting in the creation of "fringe states" with limited political power.
8. The overall growth and development of the region surrounding the Nebraska Sea can be compared to the initial westward expansion of pioneers in American history, with the sea serving as a catalyst for a new wave of progress and prosperity.

In the input article, the main events revolve around Bob Parker and Queazy, who are part of the Interplanetary Hauling & Moving Company. They receive an ethergram from Andrew S. Burnside, a wealthy man who wants an asteroid with specific dimensions and composition for a wedding in his backyard. Bob and Queazy find the asteroid, but they also find Starre Lowenthal, Burnside's granddaughter, living on it. She wants the asteroid to stay in its place to avoid marrying her fiancé, Mac.

The Saylor brothers, rivals of Bob and Queazy, also have an order for the same asteroid. They confront Bob, Queazy, and Starre on the asteroid and leave them paralyzed in space. Starre manages to save herself and the others, and they decide to work together to get the asteroid back from the Saylor brothers.

Using Starre's dumbbell-shaped ship as a "yo-yo," they attack the Saylor brothers' ship, eventually forcing them to release the asteroid. The battle is won, and the asteroid is secured for delivery.

Bob Parker, looking through the photo-amplifiers at the wedge-shaped asteroid, was plainly flabbergasted. Not in his wildest imaginings had he thought they would actually find what they were looking for.

Bob Parker: Bob is a determined and resourceful individual who is passionate about his business, Interplanetary Hauling & Moving Co. He is initially frustrated with Starre Lowenthal but eventually falls in love with her. Throughout the story, he demonstrates his quick thinking and adaptability, especially when he comes up with the "yo-yo" plan to save the asteroid.

Queazy (Quentin Zuyler): Queazy is Bob's loyal and supportive partner in their business. He is a practical and level-headed person who often brings Bob back to reality when he gets carried away. Queazy plays a crucial role in executing Bob's plan to save the asteroid and is willing to work together with Starre despite their initial conflict.

Starre Lowenthal: Starre is the granddaughter of Andrew S. Burnside and initially appears as a stubborn and uncooperative person. However, she later reveals her vulnerability and desperation to avoid marrying Mac, her fiancé. She eventually teams up with Bob and Queazy, using her resourcefulness and determination to help them save the asteroid.

Wally and Billy Saylor: The Saylor brothers are the unscrupulous and ruthless rivals of Bob and Queazy. They are willing to resort to violence and sabotage to get their way. However, they ultimately lose the battle for the asteroid due to their underestimation of Bob, Queazy, and Starre's resourcefulness and determination.

1. Bob Parker and Queazy vs. Starre Lowenthal: Initially, Bob and Queazy are in conflict with Starre as she refuses to let them take the asteroid they need to save their business. Starre wants to keep the asteroid in its place to avoid marrying her fiancé, Mac, as per her agreement with her grandfather.

2. Bob Parker and Queazy vs. Saylor brothers: The Saylor brothers are business rivals of Bob and Queazy, and they also have an order to deliver the same asteroid. The Saylor brothers resort to violence and leave Bob, Queazy, and Starre stranded in space, leading to a conflict between the two parties.

3. Starre Lowenthal vs. her grandfather and Mac: Starre is in conflict with her grandfather, Andrew S. Burnside, and her fiancé, Mac, as she does not want to marry Mac and is trying to avoid the wedding by staying on the asteroid.

4. Bob Parker's romantic feelings for Starre Lowenthal: Bob falls in love with Starre, which creates an internal conflict for him as he knows that Starre is engaged to Mac and is bound by her agreement with her grandfather.

5. The Interplanetary Commission might investigate the incident between the two rival companies, potentially leading to new regulations or restrictions on asteroid towing and interplanetary moving businesses. open-answer:
After spending three months on Earth living as Lewis Terry and experiencing human emotions, relationships, and adventures, Thig decides to return to his spaceship to report his findings to his fellow Orthans, Torp and Kam. However, upon realizing that the Orthans plan to conquer Earth and destroy its inhabitants, Thig rebels against his own kind, killing Kam and Torp in the process. He then sets the spaceship on a course back to Ortha with a warning message about the dangers of Earth, before returning to Earth himself in a smaller lifeboat. As he descends back to Earth, Thig resolves to continue living as Lewis Terry, making up for the life he had taken and protecting the family he had come to love.

Thig's feelings towards his return to Earth can be described as bittersweet for several reasons:

1. Excitement and thrill: Thig has experienced a completely different way of life on Earth, filled with love, emotions, and personal connections that were absent in his previous life on Ortha. He has enjoyed the beauty of Earth's landscapes and the excitement of living among humans. This makes him look forward to returning to Earth and continuing his life as Lewis Terry.

2. Relief: Thig has embraced his new identity as Lewis Terry and feels relief in leaving behind his past life as a member of the Ortha Horde. He is no longer bound by the strict rules and expectations of his previous existence and can now live a more fulfilling life on Earth.

3. Sadness and guilt: Despite his excitement and relief, Thig also feels sadness and guilt for several reasons. Firstly, he is responsible for the death of the real Lewis Terry, and he must now live with the knowledge that he has taken someone else's life and identity. Secondly, he knows that Ellen's love is not truly meant for him, as she believes him to be her husband, Lewis Terry. This realization causes him pain and sadness, as he deeply cares for Ellen and her happiness.

4. Determination: Thig is determined to make up for the dead man's family and ensure their happiness, even though the knowledge of his true identity will be a constant pain in his heart. This determination adds to the bittersweet nature of his feelings, as he knows that he must live a lie to protect the ones he loves.

Overall, Thig's feelings towards his return to Earth are bittersweet due to the mixture of excitement, relief, sadness, guilt, and determination that he experiences as he embraces his new life and identity while grappling with the consequences of his actions and the knowledge of his true origins.

William Shawn was the editor of The New Yorker magazine from 1952 until 1987. He was renowned for his retiring propriety and for barring anything smacking of the salacious from the magazine. Orison McCall is the main character in the input article. She is a secretary who has been selected from the Treasury Department's secretarial pool to apply for work at the William Howard Taft National Bank and Trust Company. She is tasked with reading newspapers and books aloud into a microphone. Orison is also a government spy, trying to uncover the secrets of the peculiar bank. She is described as an attractive woman, and during the story, she interacts with various characters, including the bank's Vice-President Mr. Wanji, the bank's President Dink Gerding, and his elder brother Kraft Gerding.

Orison first sees Benjamin Franklin images in the Microfabridae tank when she sneaks into the restricted seventh floor of the bank. She discovers a room filled with galvanized steel tanks, each containing a greenish fluid and millions of tiny pink spiders called Microfabridae. As she looks into one of the tanks, she briefly thinks she sees Benjamin Franklin winking up at her from the liquid. Later, when Dink Gerding, the bank president, explains that the Microfabridae are attracted to gold, Orison notices that her high-school class ring has been pitted where one of the creatures had been nibbling on it.

The most likely explanation for Orison seeing Benjamin Franklin images in the Microfabridae tank is that she was initially disoriented and confused by the strange and unexpected sight of the tanks and the tiny creatures within them. Her mind might have been trying to make sense of the situation by associating the greenish fluid and the tiny creatures with something familiar, such as currency, which features Benjamin Franklin's image on the $100 bill. Additionally, since she works in a bank and has been reading financial news, her mind could have been primed to make such associations. The fact that the Microfabridae are attracted to gold, as evidenced by the pitting on her class ring, further supports the connection between the creatures and valuable materials like currency.

open-answer:
"The Legend of Arthur" is a critical article written by economist Paul Krugman, in which he disputes the portrayal of economist Brian Arthur in a New Yorker article by John Cassidy. Krugman argues that Cassidy's article presents Arthur as the originator of the idea of increasing returns, a concept that has been around since Adam Smith and was written about by Alfred Marshall in 1890. Krugman also claims that Arthur's work on increasing returns in high-technology markets was not as groundbreaking as Cassidy suggests, as other economists had already published articles on the topic before Arthur. Furthermore, Krugman accuses Cassidy of creating a false narrative of Arthur as a lonely hero struggling against the narrow-mindedness of the economics profession, when in reality, increasing returns had been widely accepted and published in major journals for years. In response, Cassidy and other economists defend Arthur's contributions to the field and argue that Krugman's criticisms are unfounded and based on a misreading of Cassidy's article.

"The Legend of Arthur" is a critical article written by economist Paul Krugman, in which he disputes the portrayal of economist Brian Arthur in a New Yorker article by John Cassidy. Krugman argues that Cassidy's article wrongly presents Arthur as the originator of the idea of increasing returns, a concept that has been around since Adam Smith and was written about by Alfred Marshall in 1890. Krugman also claims that Arthur's work on increasing returns in high-technology markets was not as groundbreaking as Cassidy suggests, as other economists had already published articles on the topic before Arthur.

Furthermore, Krugman accuses Cassidy of creating a false narrative of Arthur as a lonely hero struggling against the narrow-mindedness of the economics profession, when in reality, increasing returns had been widely accepted and published in major journals for years. In response, Cassidy and other economists, including Kenneth J. Arrow and Ted C. Fishman, defend Arthur's contributions to the field and argue that Krugman's criticisms are unfounded and based on a misreading of Cassidy's article. They emphasize that Arthur has never claimed to be the originator of the idea of increasing returns and has always acknowledged the work of other economists in the field.

Paul Krugman's concerns in the input article can be summarized as follows:

1. He believes that John Cassidy's article in The New Yorker falsely portrays Brian Arthur as the originator of the idea of increasing returns, when in fact the concept has been around since Adam Smith and was discussed by many other economists before Arthur.

2. Krugman argues that Cassidy's article presents a misleading narrative of Arthur as a heroic figure who struggled against the mainstream economics profession, which Krugman claims is a fabrication.

3. He accuses Cassidy of being overly eager to accept a story that puts mainstream economists in a bad light, due to his apparent dislike for them.

4. Krugman suggests that Cassidy may have made up some quotes in his article, which would imply that Brian Arthur is either a fabricator or a liar.

5. He criticizes journalists, including M. Mitchell Waldrop, for being too gullible and not checking facts properly, leading to the spread of false narratives about Arthur and the economics profession.

Paul Krugman does not explicitly suggest a solution to address his concerns in the input article. However, his criticisms imply that journalists should be more diligent in checking facts, verifying quotes, and presenting a balanced and accurate portrayal of the history and contributions of various economists in their articles. This would help prevent the spread of false narratives and ensure that credit is given where it is due.

open-answer:
Feetch, full name Kalvin Feetch, is the chief engineer at the Piltdon Opener Company. He is responsible for designing the Piltdon Super-Opener, a can opener that makes cans disappear instantly upon opening. Feetch is a dedicated and skilled engineer who has worked for the company for twenty-five years. Throughout the story, he struggles with the demands of his employer, Mr. Piltdon, and his desire to conduct research and development on the mysterious "Piltdon Effect" caused by the Super-Opener. Eventually, Feetch discovers the secret behind the effect and uses it to negotiate for a majority stake in the company and the opportunity to focus on research and development.

Feetch made several discoveries throughout the story:

1. He designed the Piltdon Super-Opener, a can opener that made cans disappear instantly upon opening. This invention was a significant improvement over existing can openers in terms of speed and efficiency.

2. Feetch discovered the "Piltdon Effect," which was the mysterious phenomenon caused by the Super-Opener that made the cans disappear. He realized that the unique design of the opener, combined with the electrostatic charge generated during use, disrupted a multi-dimensional screen, causing the cans to vanish.

3. He found out that the cans were being transported to an alternate dimension called Alpha space, which was inhabited by unknown beings. These beings were not pleased with the intrusion of the cans and eventually started sending them back to Earth, causing a rain of cans all over the country.

4. Feetch identified the existence of other dimensions, including Beta space, which was devoid of life. He realized that these alternate dimensions could potentially hold an infinite number of universes, opening up the possibility of even more significant discoveries in the future.

5. Finally, Feetch designed the New Type Super-Opener, which sent cans to the uninhabited Beta space instead of Alpha space. This new design resolved the issue of cans returning to Earth and ensured the safe disposal of cans without causing any harm to other dimensions.

They claim that the intelligent have migrated to the top of business, government, and professions, while the unintelligent are falling further behind. According to Herrnstein and Murray, intelligence is substantially inherited, and efforts to improve the economic opportunities of poor people, especially poor black people, are likely to fail because their poverty is largely a result of inherited low intelligence. According to the authors, intelligence is substantially inherited, and efforts to improve the economic opportunities of poor people, especially poor black people, are likely to fail because their poverty is largely the result of inherited low intelligence. open-answer:
Commander Bob Curtis, Navigating Officer Nelson, Bos'n's Mate Joe Bradford, Czech scientist Zukor Androka, Kommander Brandt, Ensign Jack Dillon, and the German naval reservists are all involved in the Comerford's incident. Additionally, the crew members of the Comerford who were rendered unconscious and marooned on the islet also played a role in the incident.

The blame for the Comerford's incident can be attributed to several individuals and groups involved:

1. Navigating Officer Nelson: He played a significant role in the incident as he deliberately steered the Comerford to the predetermined location, allowing the German naval reservists to seize the ship. He was also in league with Bos'n's Mate Joe Bradford and had secret conversations with Zukor Androka.

2. Bos'n's Mate Joe Bradford: He was a troublemaker on the ship and conspired with Nelson to betray the Comerford. He also collaborated with the German naval reservists to take over the ship.

3. Czech scientist Zukor Androka: His invention of the "zone of silence" played a crucial role in the incident, as it disrupted radio communications and allowed the German naval reservists to take control of the ship. He also had secret conversations with Nelson and was involved in the overall plan.

4. Kommander Brandt and the German naval reservists: They were responsible for seizing the Comerford and putting the crew members ashore on the islet. They also brought additional equipment and gas tanks to the ship, further implicating their involvement in the incident.

5. Commander Bob Curtis: Although not directly responsible for the incident, his lack of suspicion and failure to recognize the signs of treachery among his crew members contributed to the Comerford's capture.

6. Ensign Jack Dillon and the rest of the Comerford's crew: While they were not directly involved in the incident, their unconsciousness and inability to defend the ship allowed the German naval reservists to take control.

In summary, the primary blame for the Comerford's incident lies with Navigating Officer Nelson, Bos'n's Mate Joe Bradford, Czech scientist Zukor Androka, and the German naval reservists led by Kommander Brandt. Commander Bob Curtis and the rest of the crew also played a role in the incident, albeit indirectly, due to their lack of awareness and inability to defend the ship.

1. fiss_book = IDENTIFY_ELEMENT(CTX, "Fiss's book") : Identify what Fiss's book is in the input article

4. ans = CONCAT(fiss_book, article_purpose, article_treatment) : Combine the information about Fiss's book, the article's purpose, and the treatment of the book in the article to form the final answer
open-answer:
Fiss's book, titled "The Irony of Free Speech," is a short book discussing the present direction of the law governing the freedom of speech. The author, Owen Fiss, is a professor at the Yale Law School and a highly regarded scholar of constitutional law. The book covers several speech issues, such as campaign-finance laws, state funding for the arts, pornography, speech codes, and equal time. Fiss argues that the current approach to speech has become increasingly permissive, and he proposes a new approach that would allow the state to silence some speakers and promote others in the name of freedom of speech. The book's main thesis is that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some.

The intent or purpose of the article is to critically analyze and discuss Owen Fiss' book "The Irony of Free Speech." The article examines Fiss' argument that the current direction of First Amendment law is problematic and that a new approach is needed to balance freedom of speech and equality. The author challenges Fiss' historical analysis of First Amendment jurisprudence and questions the feasibility of his interventionist approach to issues such as campaign finance, state funding for the arts, pornography, speech codes, and equal time. The article aims to highlight the potential pitfalls and inconsistencies in Fiss' arguments and to provoke further discussion on the complexities and ironies of free speech.

The article treats Fiss's book, "The Irony of Free Speech," as a flawed and tendentious work that distorts the history of First Amendment law and advocates for a misguided interventionist approach to free speech. The author criticizes Fiss's historical analysis, arguing that it rests on a canard that the constitutional law of free speech emerged from 19th-century classical laissez-faire liberalism, when in fact it emerged at the time of World War I and was shaped by progressives like Learned Hand, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., and Louis Brandeis. The author also takes issue with Fiss's proposal to replace the traditional approach to free speech, which tries to push the state as far out of the picture as possible, with a different approach that tries to get the state farther into the picture. The article contends that Fiss's interventionist approach is problematic and difficult to apply consistently across different cases, such as pornography, hate speech, arts grants, campaign finance, and equal-time provisions. Furthermore, the author argues that Fiss's analysis of specific cases, like the Mapplethorpe case, is wrongheaded and demonstrates the perils of his interventionist approach. Overall, the article presents a negative critique of Fiss's book and its arguments.

open-answer:
Eddie is a young boy who is interested in atomic science and uranium prospecting. He is the son of Mr. Taylor, the head of the atomic-science department at Oceanview College. Eddie often goes on prospecting trips with his friend Teena, and he is knowledgeable about radioisotopes and atomic reactors.


Eddie has a considerable knowledge about radioactivity, particularly about radioisotopes and atomic reactors. He understands that radioisotopes are materials that have been "cooked" in an atomic reactor until they are "hot" with radioactivity. He knows that when carefully controlled, the radiation stored up in radioisotopes can be used in many beneficial ways. Eddie is also aware of the process of atomic reactions in a uranium pile, which is made up of hundreds of graphite bricks with small bits of uranium scattered between them. He explains that uranium atoms are radioactive, constantly splitting up and sending out rays, creating a chain reaction. However, atomic piles control the reaction by keeping the splitting-up atoms apart, preventing an uncontrolled explosion. The whole pile is covered by a shield of concrete about eight feet thick to protect workmen from the dangerous rays.


Eddie first learns about the missing isotope when he notices his father's worried expression and hears him talking urgently on the phone. He asks his father what's wrong, and Mr. Taylor explains that the radioisotope shipment he was expecting had been stolen. Eddie is shocked and asks his father several questions about the theft, including how it could have happened and what the thieves could do with the stolen isotope. His father explains that the theft was likely carried out by spies who knew how to handle the dangerous radioactive material. Eddie later discusses the theft with Teena and her mother, explaining what a radioisotope is and the potential dangers it poses if not handled properly.


Eddie feels anxious and concerned about the missing isotope. He is eager to discuss the situation with someone, but he knows he shouldn't bother his father with any more questions. He goes to Teena's house to talk about it, and he tries to explain what a radioisotope is and why it's dangerous. Eddie is also worried about the possibility that spies might have stolen the isotope and the potential consequences of that.

In a hypothetical situation where Eddie is not knowledgeable about radioactivity, his reaction to the missing isotope would be significantly different. He would likely feel confused and less concerned about the theft, as he would not understand the significance of the stolen radioisotope and the potential dangers it poses. Eddie would be unable to discuss the safety measures taken by atomic reactors to control chain reactions and prevent explosions, and he would also be unaware of the different types of radioactive rays and their varying levels of danger and penetration. This lack of knowledge would make him less able to contribute to any discussions or efforts to recover the stolen isotope. Additionally, his interest in prospecting for uranium and using a Geiger counter would be less informed, potentially leading to misunderstandings or misinterpretations of the readings he gets from the device. Overall, Eddie's emotional response to the missing isotope would be less intense and more detached due to his lack of understanding of the situation.

The protagonist, Yandro, is believed to be the prophesied "Conquering Stranger" who will lead the people of Dondromogon to victory against their enemies, the Newcomers. As Yandro struggles to understand his new identity and purpose, he encounters various characters, including Doriza, a gentlewoman of the guard, and Sporr, a mystic doctor. The story follows Yandro's journey as he navigates the challenges of his new life and attempts to fulfill his destiny.

The central theme of the story revolves around the protagonist, Yandro, who is mysteriously transported to the planet Dondromogon with no memory of his past. The theme explores the concept of destiny, the struggle between good and evil, and the challenges faced by an individual who is thrust into a leadership role without any prior knowledge or experience.

In the input article, Owen Fiss is identified as a professor at the Yale Law School and a highly regarded scholar of constitutional law. The article discusses Fiss' book, "The Irony of Free Speech," in which he critiques the current direction of First Amendment law and proposes a new approach to speech regulation. Fiss argues that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, and he advocates for specific groups he regards as politically disadvantaged, such as women, gays, victims of racial-hate speech, the poor, and people who are critical of market capitalism.

The main motive of Owen Fiss, as discussed in the input article, is to critique the current direction of First Amendment law and propose a new approach to speech regulation. Fiss argues that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, in order to promote a more equal and robust public debate. He advocates for specific groups he regards as politically disadvantaged, such as women, gays, victims of racial-hate speech, the poor, and people who are critical of market capitalism. Fiss believes that by allowing the state to silence some speakers and promote others, it would still be in the name of freedom of speech, and would ultimately lead to a more inclusive and diverse public discourse.

open-answer:
In the input article, Owen Fiss is identified as a professor at the Yale Law School and a highly regarded scholar of constitutional law. The article discusses Fiss' short book on the present direction of the law governing the freedom of speech. Fiss believes that the current direction of First Amendment law is a bad one and proposes a new approach that would permit the state to silence some speakers and promote others, in the name of freedom of speech. The article critiques Fiss' arguments and the historical analysis he presents in his book.

The relation between Fiss' opinions and the current laws regarding self-expression lies in his critique of the First Amendment law and its application to various issues connected to freedom of speech and self-expression. Fiss believes that the current direction of First Amendment law is problematic and proposes a new approach that would allow the state to silence some speakers and promote others, in the name of freedom of speech. He argues that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, which he refers to as the "irony" of free speech. 

Fiss suggests that liberals should stop thinking about the conflict between liberty and equality and start thinking about it as a conflict between two kinds of liberty: social vs. individual. This perspective challenges the current understanding of First Amendment law, which the author argues was not based on the right to individual self-expression but on the democratic need for full and open political debate. 

Fiss' opinions also touch upon various issues related to freedom of speech and self-expression, such as campaign finance, equal-time provisions, state funding for the arts, pornography, and speech codes. In each of these areas, Fiss generally favors state intervention on political grounds, which contrasts with the current laws that aim to protect individual rights to self-expression and limit state interference. For example, in the case of arts policy, Fiss proposes that the criteria for funding should be political, favoring unorthodox art that represents a viewpoint worthy of state support, rather than using strictly artistic criteria or getting the state out of the business altogether. This stance highlights the tension between Fiss' opinions and the current laws regarding self-expression, as he advocates for a more interventionist approach to ensure a more balanced and inclusive public discourse.

open-answer:
In the input article, Owen Fiss critiques the current direction of First Amendment law and proposes a new approach to freedom of speech. His main ideas include:

1. The current approach to speech has become increasingly permissive, with courts becoming more reluctant to allow the state to interfere with individual speakers' rights. Fiss believes it is time to roll back this permissiveness and adopt a new approach that allows the state to silence some speakers and promote others, in the name of freedom of speech.

2. Fiss argues that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, which he refers to as the "irony" of free speech.

3. He advocates for specific groups he regards as politically disadvantaged, such as women, gays, victims of racial-hate speech, the poor, and people who are critical of market capitalism. He aims to design a constitutional theory that enables these groups to enlist the state in efforts to suppress speech they dislike or subsidize speech they do like, without violating the First Amendment.

4. Fiss suggests that liberals should stop thinking about the conflict between liberty and equality and start thinking about it as a conflict between two kinds of liberty: social vs. individual. He believes that the First Amendment was intended to foster "uninhibited, robust, and wide-open" debate in society as a whole, and that speech that inhibits or monopolizes that debate should fall outside the protection of the law.

5. He discusses several speech issues, such as campaign-finance laws, state funding for the arts, pornography, speech codes, and equal time, generally favoring state intervention on political grounds in each of these areas.

6. Fiss proposes that the state should subsidize art that enhances the "robustness" of the debate and prefers unorthodox art, representing viewpoints that have been historically excluded.

The intended influence of Owen Fiss's ideas on people in the input article is to encourage a reevaluation of the current direction of First Amendment law and promote a new approach to freedom of speech that balances individual and social liberties. By arguing that true freedom of speech requires suppressing the speech of some in order to promote a more inclusive and robust public debate, Fiss aims to shift the focus from individual self-expression to the overall health of democratic discourse. He advocates for specific politically disadvantaged groups, such as women, gays, victims of racial-hate speech, the poor, and critics of market capitalism, and seeks to design a constitutional theory that allows these groups to enlist the state's help in suppressing or subsidizing speech without violating the First Amendment. Fiss discusses various speech issues, favoring state intervention on political grounds, and proposes that the state should subsidize art that enhances the robustness of the debate and represents historically excluded viewpoints. The intended impact of these ideas on people is to foster a more equitable and diverse public discourse, empower marginalized groups, and challenge the traditional understanding of free speech in the context of the First Amendment.

open-answer:
In the input article, Owen Fiss holds several beliefs regarding the freedom of speech and its current direction in law. He believes that the present approach to speech has become increasingly permissive, with courts becoming more reluctant to allow the state to interfere with individual speakers' rights. Fiss proposes a new approach that would allow the state to silence some speakers and promote others in the name of freedom of speech. He argues that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, which he refers to as the "irony" of free speech.

Fiss also believes that the constitutional law of free speech emerged from 19th-century classical laissez-faire liberalism and that contemporary liberals find themselves in a bind between liberty and equality. He suggests that liberals should reframe this conflict as one between social and individual liberty, with the First Amendment intended to foster "uninhibited, robust, and wide-open" debate in society as a whole. According to Fiss, speech that inhibits or monopolizes that debate should fall outside the protection of the law.

Furthermore, Fiss believes that the American public is less enlightened than it could be due to people being denied access to opinions and information that would enlighten them. He thinks that the state should interfere with speech bullies, such as pornographers, who "silence" women, and subsidize the speech of the unorthodox, such as Robert Mapplethorpe. In the case of arts policy, Fiss rejects the idea of using strictly artistic criteria for funding and instead proposes that the criteria should be political, with the NEA subsidizing art that will enhance the "robustness" of the debate and preferring unorthodox art that represents a viewpoint worthy of its support.

In the input article, Owen Fiss expresses several opinions related to the present direction of the law governing the freedom of speech. He believes that the current approach to speech has become increasingly permissive, and he proposes a new approach that would allow the state to silence some speakers and promote others in the name of freedom of speech. Fiss argues that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, which he refers to as the "irony" of free speech. He suggests that liberals should stop thinking about the conflict between liberty and equality and start thinking about it as a conflict between two kinds of liberty: social vs. individual. Fiss also believes that the need for equal-time laws is as urgent today as it was in the 1970s, despite the proliferation of media outlets. In the case of arts policy, Fiss rejects the solutions of getting the state out of the business altogether or using strictly artistic criteria for funding, and instead proposes that the criteria should be political, with the NEA preferring unorthodox art that represents a viewpoint worthy of its support.

open-answer:
The topic discussed in the input article is the direction of the law governing the freedom of speech, particularly in the context of the First Amendment in the United States. The article focuses on the book "The Irony of Free Speech" by Owen Fiss, a professor at the Yale Law School and a highly regarded scholar of constitutional law. Fiss argues that the current direction of First Amendment law is a bad one and proposes a new approach that would allow the state to silence some speakers and promote others, in the name of freedom of speech.

Fiss believes that true freedom of speech for all requires suppressing the speech of some, which he refers to as the "irony" in his title. He suggests that liberals should stop thinking about the conflict between liberty and equality and start thinking about it as a conflict between two kinds of liberty: social vs. individual. According to Fiss, the First Amendment was intended to foster "uninhibited, robust, and wide-open" debate in society as a whole, and speech that inhibits or monopolizes that debate should fall outside the protection of the law.

The article critiques Fiss' historical analysis, arguing that the constitutional law of free speech did not emerge from 19th-century classical laissez-faire liberalism, as Fiss claims, but rather from the progressive era of the early 20th century, with key figures such as Learned Hand, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., and Louis Brandeis. The author contends that Fiss' portrayal of the history of First Amendment jurisprudence is distorted to fit within the conventional academic view that our problems are mostly the consequences of an antiquated and discreditable ideology of liberal individualism.

Fiss' book discusses several speech issues, including campaign-finance laws, state funding for the arts, pornography, speech codes, and equal time. His general inclination is to favor state intervention, on political grounds, in each of those areas. The article questions the feasibility of Fiss' interventionist approach, arguing that it is difficult to calculate the effects of redistributing the right to speak and that such efforts at cultural engineering can have unintended consequences.

4. Fiss addresses several speech issues in his book, including campaign-finance laws, state funding for the arts, pornography, speech codes, and equal time.
5. Fiss believes that the need for equal-time laws is as urgent today as it was in the 1970s.
6. Fiss' analysis of the Mapplethorpe case suggests that the NEA should subsidize art that will enhance the "robustness" of the debate and should prefer unorthodox art.
7. The author of the article argues that Fiss' portrayal of the history of First Amendment jurisprudence is distorted and that the law governing the freedom of speech does not emerge out of libertarianism.

5. Dole's accusations against the Times could be interpreted as an expression of bitterness and resentment towards the Eastern establishment, which may not resonate well with moderate and independent voters.

The club's primary purpose is to collect and repair second-hand clothing for charity. As a result of the experiment, the sewing club evolves into a larger organization, eventually becoming the Watashaw Mutual Trade and Civic Development Corporation, and expanding beyond the town of Watashaw.

The reason behind Caswell's opinion on the growth of the Watashaw sewing club is based on the organizational structure and incentives that he and the university president built into the club. They designed the club to have a strong motivation for existing members to recruit new members, as well as making it difficult for members to leave the club. This created a snowball effect, where the club would continue to grow rapidly, following a logarithmic curve and doubling in size at regular intervals. Caswell believes that this growth will continue, eventually encompassing the entire world population. Harris has attracted the attention of the media and politicians who are "looking into" whether he can be stopped. He cites his experience as a horse breeder and asks, "We bid for everything else in this society--why not eggs?" Harris constantly refers to the donors as his "girls" and describes them like cattle. He gets a 20 percent commission on each winning bid, though he takes no responsibility for executing financial transactions or medical procedures.

The main flaw in Harris' plan to sell the eggs of fashion models is that it is based on superficial and misleading criteria for selecting egg donors. The plan focuses solely on the physical appearance of the models, without considering other important factors such as their health, intelligence, and genetic background. Additionally, the plan exploits both the buyers and the sellers, as it takes advantage of desperate couples trying to conceive and struggling models looking for financial gain. Furthermore, Harris takes no responsibility for the medical procedures or financial transactions involved, which raises concerns about the safety, legality, and ethical implications of the auction. Finally, the plan promotes a harmful preoccupation with physical beauty over more meaningful qualities such as character and intelligence, and it raises concerns about the potential for genetic discrimination and the creation of a "super-race" of beautiful people.

1. unmade_beds = IDENTIFY_ELEMENT(CTX, "Unmade Beds") : Identify what Unmade Beds refers to in the input article
2. slums_beverly_hills = IDENTIFY_ELEMENT(CTX, "The Slums of Beverly Hills") : Identify what The Slums of Beverly Hills refers to in the input article
3. similarities = FIND_COMMON(CTX, unmade_beds, slums_beverly_hills, "similarities") : Find the common ground, characteristics, or commonalities between Unmade Beds and The Slums of Beverly Hills given the input article
4. ans = CONCAT(unmade_beds, slums_beverly_hills, similarities) : Combine the information about Unmade Beds, The Slums of Beverly Hills, and their similarities to form the final answer
open-answer:
Unmade Beds is a "directed" documentary film by Nicholas Barker that tracks four aging New Yorkers--two men, two women--through their lonely dating rituals. The director selected his four subjects from many hundreds of potential candidates, followed them around for months, and then scripted their monologues and dialogues to reflect what he says he saw. The film has been criticized for its stylized approach and manipulation of its subjects' lives in the name of "larger dramatic truths."

The Slums of Beverly Hills refers to a movie that walks a line between two genres: coming-of-age sex comedy and autobiographical monologue. The film is written and directed by Tamara Jenkins, who has an eye for absurd juxtapositions that was obviously sharpened by the pain of her nomadic upbringing. The protagonist, played by Natasha Lyonne, spends her teenage years being shuttled with her two brothers from one cheap dive to another in the 90210 ZIP code, all because her egregiously unsuccessful father, played by Alan Arkin, wants them to be educated in the best schools. The film also features Marisa Tomei as the protagonist's cousin.

Both Unmade Beds and The Slums of Beverly Hills blur the lines between genres, with Unmade Beds being a "directed" documentary that incorporates scripted scenes and stylized material, while The Slums of Beverly Hills combines coming-of-age sex comedy with autobiographical monologue. Both films focus on the personal lives and struggles of their subjects, with Unmade Beds exploring the lonely dating rituals of four aging New Yorkers and The Slums of Beverly Hills following a teenager's nomadic upbringing in cheap accommodations within the prestigious 90210 ZIP code. Additionally, both films have been criticized for certain aspects of their storytelling, with Unmade Beds receiving backlash for its manipulation of its subjects' lives and The Slums of Beverly Hills being noted for its lack of narrative payoff in some episodes.

They also appreciate the director's skill in getting strong performances from the cast, including Robert Duvall, Sydney Pollack, William H. Macy, and Kathleen Quinlan. However, the author criticizes the movie's philosophical voice-overs, which they find pretentious and lacking geopolitical context. A Civil Action is a movie based on Jonathan Harr's book about a reckless personal injury lawyer, Jan Schlichtmann, played by John Travolta. The author finds the movie to be a sturdy piece of work, an old-fashioned conversion narrative with some high-tech zip. The author praises the movie's sequence that cuts back and forth between Jerome Facher's (Robert Duvall) Harvard Law School lectures and Schlichtmann's fumbling prosecution, as well as the sterling bit performances from Sydney Pollack, William H. Macy, and Kathleen Quinlan. However, the author notes that the movie takes a more surface approach, sticking to legal minutiae and rarely digging for the deeper evil.

open-answer:
Bob Dole is the Republican nominee for the 1996 U.S. presidential election, who is mentioned throughout the input article. The article discusses Dole's attacks on the New York Times, accusing the newspaper of biased coverage against him and favoring his opponent, President Bill Clinton. Dole's anger towards the Times is portrayed as stemming from a feeling of being shut out of the Eastern establishment and a sense of unfair treatment by the media.


The character who didn't agree with Dole about the way the Times treated him is Times Washington Editor Andrew Rosenthal. He expressed bewilderment at the complaints from Dole's campaign and defended the paper's coverage, stating that they don't make editorial judgments based on disposition towards Dole. Rosenthal also pointed out that the Times ran an editor's note acknowledging a mistake in truncating a quote and explained the paper's practice of running a lengthy series on the incumbent's record.

The conflict or concern related to the way the Times treated Dole in the input article can be summarized as follows:

1. Dole's campaign staff accused the Times of misunderstanding his position on abortion in December 1995.
2. In May, the Times placed a major address about welfare by Dole on Page 19 of the business section, which angered his campaign.
3. Dole's press secretary, Nelson Warfield, publicly confronted Times reporter Katharine Seelye, accusing her of misquoting Dole and distorting the accuracy of the paper's coverage.
4. The campaign complained about the Times' focus on Dole's verbal miscues and unflattering photographs, as well as the paper's alleged soft treatment of Clinton.
5. Seelye's reporting style has been described as "cinema verité," capturing Dole's every mumble, repetition, and verbal miscue, which can make him look ridiculous.
6. The Times has defended its coverage, stating that it has been tough on Dole due to the campaign's internal problems and not because of any bias.

1. times_treatment = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "Times treatment", "Dole") : Find and summarize all the ways the Times treated Dole unfairly in the input article

open-answer:
The Times has been accused of treating Dole unfairly in several ways:

1. Burying important stories about Dole: The Times placed a major address about welfare by Dole on Page 19 of the business section, which the Dole campaign felt was unfair treatment.
2. Misquoting Dole: The Dole campaign accused Times reporter Katharine Seelye of misquoting Dole on numerous occasions, leading to distorted coverage.
3. Focusing on negative aspects of Dole's campaign: The Times was accused of excessively focusing on Dole's mistakes and internal campaign problems, rather than the bigger picture of his policies and positions.
4. Unflattering portrayal of Dole: Seelye's "cinema verité" style of quoting Dole made him appear ridiculous by capturing every mumble, repetition, and verbal miscue.
5. Unequal treatment compared to Clinton: The Dole campaign felt that the Times gave Clinton more favorable coverage, including a nine-part series on his record, better photographs, and less scrutiny of his mistakes.

open-answer:
Alis Garet is a nineteen-year-old student at Cavalier Institute and the daughter of Professor Osbert Garet. She is described as having a good figure, mocking eyes, a pert nose, and a mouth that seems perpetually waiting to be kissed. Alis is a skeptic and does not believe in her father's theories on magnology. She befriends Don Cort, the protagonist, and accompanies him on his investigation of the edge of the levitated town of Superior.


1. "You're Mr. Cort," she said. "Won't you join me?"
2. "You'd be hard to miss. I'm Alis—that's A-l-i-s, not A-l-i-c-e—Garet. Are you with the FBI? Or did you escape from jail?"
3. "I'll admit to the double entendre ," Alis said. "What I meant—for now—was that we can stroll out to where Superior used to be attached to the rest of Ohio and see how the Earth is getting along without us."
4. "Don't! You'll fall off!"
5. "Just in case a high wind comes along," she said.
6. "It isn't? Then where is it going?"
7. "This is new," Alis said.
8. "Look how it comes in spurts," Alis said.
9. "North Lake, maybe," Alis said. "People fish there but nobody's allowed to swim."
10. "I don't know."
11. "I know one thing—I wouldn't be there holding your ankle while you found out."
12. "It's impressive, isn't it?" she said. "I wonder if that's Indiana way over there?"
13. "We could tell by the sun, silly."
14. "Transportation?" Alis squeezed the arm she was holding. "Why? Don't you like it here?"
15. "You're still quite acceptable, if a bit whiskery." She stopped, still holding his arm, and he turned so they were face to face. "So kiss me," she said, "before you deteriorate."

Alis Garet is a 19-year-old student at Cavalier Institute and the daughter of Professor Osbert Garet. She is described as willowy, blonde, and attractive, with a good figure, mocking eyes, a pert nose, and a mouth that seems perpetually waiting to be kissed. Alis is a skeptic and a natural-born needler, having questioned her father's theories on magnology since she was 16. She is also a demon class-cutter, which is why she is still a senior at her age. Alis is friendly and open, inviting Don to join her for breakfast and later accompanying him to explore the edge of the levitated town. She is also adventurous and daring, as she goes with Don to investigate the source of South Creek despite the potential danger. Throughout the story, Alis remains a supportive and curious companion to Don, helping him navigate the strange situation they find themselves in.

The most significant problems mentioned in the input article are:

1. The extreme heat on the Brightside of Mercury, with temperatures reaching 770° F at perihelion, making it the hottest place in the Solar System apart from the surface of the Sun.
2. The treacherous terrain, including active volcanoes, faults, and craters, which makes navigation and travel difficult and dangerous.
3. The presence of molten lead pits hidden beneath the surface, posing a risk to the vehicles and crew.
4. The constant, unceasing thirst experienced by the crew, which could lead to nephritis if not managed carefully.
5. The personality clashes and tensions within the crew, particularly between McIvers and the rest of the team, which could potentially jeopardize the mission's success.

1. The extreme heat on the Brightside of Mercury is caused by its close proximity to the Sun and its position during perihelion, when it is closest to the Sun in its orbit. This heat poses a significant challenge for the crew and their equipment, as they must rely on advanced insulating suits and vehicles to protect them from the intense temperatures.

2. The treacherous terrain on the Brightside of Mercury is a result of its geological activity, including active volcanoes, faults, and craters. This makes navigation and travel difficult and dangerous, as the crew must constantly assess the stability of the ground and find safe passages through the landscape.

3. The presence of molten lead pits hidden beneath the surface is another hazard caused by the extreme heat and geological activity on the Brightside. These pits pose a risk to the vehicles and crew, as they can become trapped or damaged if they inadvertently drive into one.

4. The constant, unceasing thirst experienced by the crew is a psychological and physiological response to the extreme heat and harsh conditions on the Brightside. This thirst must be managed carefully to prevent dehydration and the risk of nephritis, a potentially life-threatening kidney condition.

5. The personality clashes and tensions within the crew are a result of the high-stress environment and the unique challenges posed by the Brightside Crossing. These tensions could potentially jeopardize the mission's success if not managed effectively, as teamwork and cooperation are essential for overcoming the numerous obstacles and hazards encountered during the journey.

Charlie, also known as Stardust Charlie, is a veteran spaceman who was part of Everson's first trip to the Moon nearly twenty-five years ago. He is the Chief Jetman on the Lunar Lady, a commercial ore ship on a shuttle between Luna City and White Sands. Charlie is a close friend and mentor to the protagonist, Ben, and has a significant impact on Ben's life and decisions. He is described as a wizened little man with a mop of steel-gray hair, a scarred face due to an atomic blowup on one of the old Moon ships, and an old-fashioned black suit. Charlie is a symbol of the old-time spacemen who valued courage, adventure, and exploration above all else.

Charlie came to visit for several reasons. Firstly, he wanted to attend Ben's graduation from the U.S. Academy of Interplanetary Flight, as he had played a significant role in Ben's journey to become a spaceman. Charlie had been a father figure, mentor, and friend to Ben, and his recommendation had helped Ben become a cadet at the Academy. Secondly, Charlie wanted to spend his 24-hour liberty with Ben, celebrating their achievements and shared passion for space travel. He hoped to have a memorable night with Ben, celebrating as spacemen should, before returning to his duties on the Lunar Lady. Lastly, Charlie's visit served as a way for him to indirectly share his life experiences and the consequences of his choices with Ben, helping Ben make a pivotal decision about his own future.

open-answer:
Harris, or Ron Harris, is a soft-porn entrepreneur who started an online auction for the eggs of fashion models on his website, ronsangels.com. The site invites visitors to "bid on eggs from beautiful, healthy and intelligent women." Harris has attracted the attention of the media and politicians who are "looking into" whether he can be stopped.

1. Designer babies: The egg auction could lead to the creation of "designer babies" as people bid on eggs from beautiful, healthy, and intelligent women, potentially steering the future of human breeding towards genetic engineering.

2. Failed expectations: The children born from these eggs may not necessarily inherit the desired traits, as genetics is a complex process and the child could inherit a mix of traits from both parents.

3. Survival of the fittest: The rich may be able to afford these eggs, potentially leading to a "super-race" and a society separated into "genetic haves and have-nots."

4. Survival of the unfittest: The children produced by the egg auction may inherit undesirable traits from their parents, such as dishonesty or superficiality.

5. Health concerns: Beauty may not necessarily convey health, and the children born from these eggs may not be as healthy as expected.

6. Intelligence vs. beauty: The focus on beauty may overshadow the importance of intelligence, leading to children who may be attractive but not necessarily intelligent or successful.

7. Exploitation of buyers and sellers: Harris' auction may exploit desperate buyers and sellers, with the former being susceptible to false dreams and the latter potentially being unaware of the health risks of donating eggs.

8. Internet issues: The auction may raise concerns about the role of the Internet in facilitating such transactions, as well as the potential for fraud and deception.

9. Unintended consequences: The children born from these eggs may face various psychological and social challenges, such as parental disappointment, forced career paths, or unwanted attention.

10. Genetic self-interest: The desire to pass on one's own genes may outweigh the appeal of purchasing eggs from attractive donors, potentially limiting the success of Harris' auction.

11. Transcending beauty: The focus on physical attractiveness may prompt a reevaluation of societal values and a push towards transcending the prejudice in favor of beauty.

The article discusses a beer-tasting experiment conducted by a team of Microsoft employees, focusing on comparing a variety of top-of-the-line beers. The experiment involved nine testers who sampled and rated 10 different beers, including one holdover from a previous test (Samuel Adams Boston Lager), one import (Bass), and one macrobrew (Michelob Hefeweizen). The beers were rated based on overall quality points, descriptions of taste, best and worst rankings, and categorization of beer types. The results showed that Michelob Hefeweizen was the highest-rated beer and also the cheapest, while Pyramid Hefeweizen was the least popular. The testers had difficulty accurately identifying the beer types and brands, with only one tester correctly identifying two or more beers. The experiment raises questions about the importance of factors such as labels, bottles, and origin in beer preferences and suggests further research possibilities.

1. Michelob Hefeweizen was the highest-rated beer in the experiment, indicating that it was the most preferred among the testers.
2. Pyramid Hefeweizen was the least popular beer among the testers.
3. Testers had difficulty accurately identifying beer types and brands, suggesting that familiarity plays a significant role in recognizing specific beers.
4. Anheuser-Busch products performed well in the taste tests, with Busch and Michelob Hefeweizen both being top performers in their respective rounds.
5. The experiment showed that factors such as labels, bottles, and origin may play a significant role in beer preferences, as the blind taste test results differed from what the testers might have expected.
6. The results of the experiment suggest that there is a difference between the concept of "bestness" in terms of being the most unusual or distinctive and being unobtrusive and consistently acceptable.
7. The experiment raises questions about the importance of factors such as labels, bottles, and origin in beer preferences and suggests further research possibilities.

open-answer:
The Circuit City story in the input article revolves around a customer, K., who faced issues with the company's customer service when trying to get his television repaired. K.'s television, which was only a year old, had been in the Circuit City shop for a week, and when he called to inquire about it, he was told to "check back next week." When he asked if someone from the store could call him with more information, he was refused. Weeks went by, and K. still did not have his television back. At one point, when K. expressed his desire to get his television back, a Circuit City employee asked him, "Don't you have another television in your house?"

After more than a month, K. finally received his television back, but only after spending hours on the phone and missing days at work. When K. complained about the situation, a Circuit City official told him that the case was "handled perfectly." Another official, Morgan Stewart in public relations, claimed that Circuit City became a big and successful company by treating customers better than the other guy. The Shopping Avenger and his sidekick, Tad the Deputy Avenger, are seeking input from other Circuit City customers to determine if the company does, in fact, treat its customers better than the other guy.

The U-Haul story in the input article revolves around the company's non-reservation reservation policy, which has led to numerous customer complaints. One correspondent, B.R., shared his experience of reserving a moving truck with U-Haul for his brother's move. Despite having a reservation, when they arrived at the U-Haul store, they were informed that their reserved truck had not yet been returned. They asked if they could rent one of the many trucks sitting idle in the parking lot, but the clerk laughed and said the keys to those trucks were lost. Frustrated, B.R. and his brother went to Ryder, which had a truck available for them. The Shopping Avenger has not received a response from U-Haul's spokeswoman Johna Burke regarding the company's reservation policy, but several correspondents have mentioned that they will be taking their business to Ryder or Budget based on the information provided in the column.

open-answer:
In American Beauty, the protagonist Lester Burnham (played by Kevin Spacey) is a middle-aged man who feels trapped and sedated in his suburban life. He works as a reporter for a media magazine and is married to Carolyn (Annette Bening), a real-estate broker who is obsessed with maintaining appearances and achieving success. Lester's life takes a turn when he becomes infatuated with a high school cheerleader named Angela (Mena Suvari), who happens to be friends with his daughter, Jane (Thora Burch). This infatuation leads Lester to rediscover his passion for life, as he starts working out, smoking marijuana, and standing up to his controlling wife and unsatisfying job.

The film also delves into the lives of the Burnhams' neighbors, including a homophobic ex-Marine colonel (Chris Cooper) who struggles with his own repressed emotions and his son, Ricky (Wes Bentley), a voyeuristic teenager who finds beauty in unexpected places, such as a video of a plastic bag dancing in the wind. Ricky shares his unique perspective with Jane, and they form a bond over their shared sense of alienation from their families and society.

Throughout the movie, the characters grapple with their personal demons, societal expectations, and the search for meaning in their lives. The film explores themes of suburban malaise, the emptiness of material success, and the importance of finding beauty and connection in a seemingly loveless world. The story is told through a mix of dark comedy, drama, and surreal imagery, creating a unique and thought-provoking cinematic experience.

Thaddeus Funston is a patient at a mental institution who is introduced in the story as an institutionalized psychotic. He is described as a frowning, intense patient who is working with modeling clay in the hospital's arts and crafts shop. Thaddeus claims to have made an atom bomb out of the clay, which is initially dismissed as a delusion by Miss Abercrombie, the manual therapist. However, later that night, an explosion occurs at the arts and crafts shop, destroying the building and leaving a mushroom-shaped cloud in its wake.

The explosion attracts the attention of the military and the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC), who investigate the incident. They eventually decide to give Thaddeus another chance to create an atomic bomb under their supervision. Thaddeus is taken to the AEC's atomic testing grounds in Nevada, where he creates another clay bomb. This bomb also detonates, causing a massive explosion and further confirming Thaddeus's ability to create atomic devices from modeling clay.

Thaddeus is then taken to the Pentagon, where the joint chiefs of staff discuss his case. Despite the evidence, a four-star general dismisses Thaddeus's abilities as a ridiculous story. In response, Thaddeus stares out the window at the Washington Monument, which subsequently lifts off its base and vanishes into space on a tail of flame, proving his extraordinary abilities once again.

open-answer:
In the story, Kolin is a character who is unhappy with the oppressive regime on his home planet, Haurtoz. While exploring a new planet after their ship is damaged, Kolin encounters a tree named Ashlew, which is actually a man who has transformed into a tree. Ashlew tells Kolin about the Life, a powerful entity on the planet that can help individuals change their form. Intrigued by the idea of escaping his life on Haurtoz and becoming something else, Kolin considers various forms he could take, eventually deciding on becoming a cloud of spores.

As a cloud of spores, Kolin is able to infiltrate the minds and bodies of other people, including his fellow crew members on the ship. His ultimate goal is to reform the oppressive Planetary State of Haurtoz and create a Planetary Mind, a collective consciousness that would bring about positive change. Throughout the story, Kolin's thoughts and actions revolve around his desire to escape his current life and the possibility of becoming a tree or another form that would allow him to achieve his goals.

Kolin feels intrigued and curious about the idea of becoming a tree, as it offers him a chance to escape the oppressive regime on Haurtoz. This can be seen in the following paragraphs:

"Maybe I'd better stay a while," he muttered. "I don't know where I am."
"You're about fifty feet up," the sighing voice informed him. "You ought to let me tell you how the Life helps you change form. You don't have to be a tree."
"No?"
"Uh-uh! Some of the boys that landed with me wanted to get around and see things. Lots changed to animals or birds. One even stayed a man—on the outside anyway. Most of them have to change as the bodies wear out, which I don't, and some made bad mistakes tryin' to be things they saw on other planets."
"I wouldn't want to do that, Mr. Ashlew."

"Silenced but doubting, Kolin permitted himself to try the dream on for size. He considered what form might most easily escape the notice of search parties and still be tough enough to live a long time without renewal."

Mr. Oyster is an elderly, wealthy gentleman who appears as a client in the story. He believes in time travel and wants to hire Simon, the protagonist, to find a time traveler for him. Mr. Oyster is convinced that time travelers would be present at the Oktoberfest in Munich, as it would be an ideal event for them to study people and remain inconspicuous. He is willing to pay a considerable amount of money for Simon's services, including a $50,000 bonus if Simon brings him a time traveler.


In the story Simon tells Mr. Oyster, he describes how he took Mr. Oyster's money and went to Munich to attend the Oktoberfest in search of time travelers. He meets a man named Arth, who claims to be from the future, and they spend the night drinking together. The next day, Simon wakes up with a terrible hangover and decides to return to New York. However, he finds himself back at the beginning of the story, with Mr. Oyster still waiting for his receipt. Simon realizes that the time travelers won't allow the space-time continuum track to be altered, so they keep resetting him back to the start. He tells Mr. Oyster that the only thing he can bring back from the future is a hangover, and he refuses to go through the experience again.

The intent of the story Simon tells Mr. Oyster is to demonstrate the futility of trying to bring back anything from the future, particularly the secret of eternal life and youth, due to the time travelers' unwillingness to allow the space-time continuum track to be altered. By sharing his experience of attending the Oktoberfest in Munich, meeting a man from the future, and being repeatedly reset back to the start, Simon aims to dissuade Mr. Oyster from pursuing his quest for time travelers and to show that the only thing he can bring back from the future is a hangover.

Initially, Simon is uninterested in the proposal, but he eventually takes up the assignment.

Upon arriving in Munich, Simon attends the Oktoberfest and meets a man named Arth, who claims to be from the year 2183. They spend the night drinking together, and Simon experiences a series of time loops and hangovers. Each time he tries to bring back information about time travel or the future, he finds himself back at the beginning of the story, with no memory of the previous loops.

Simon eventually realizes that the time travelers are not going to allow the space-time continuum track to be altered, and that they are resetting his timeline to prevent any changes to the past. He concludes that the only thing he can bring back from the future is a hangover, and decides to give up on the assignment.

Simon initially finds the idea of time travel ridiculous and amusing, as evidenced by his reluctance to take up Mr. Oyster's assignment and his plan to have fun at the Oktoberfest while making up stories for his reports. The car is filled with horrified silence, as everyone realizes the faux pas of making a cemetery joke in the presence of someone who has just returned from beyond the grave.
